turns.content: I'm looking for some new comedy specials to watch on Netflix. Any recommendations?

Netflix has an amazing collection of comedy specials. Here are some popular and highly-recommended ones:

**Recent Releases**

1. **Trevor Noah: Son of Patricia** (2018) - Noah's latest special, where he tackles politics, identity, and growing up in South Africa.
2. **John Mulaney: The Comeback Kid** (2015) - A classic from Mulaney, where he shares hilarious stories about his childhood, relationships, and getting older.
3. **Hannah Gadsby: Douglas** (2020) - A groundbreaking special that tackles trauma, comedy, and identity, from the Australian comedian.
4. **Hasan Minhaj: Homecoming King** (2017) - Minhaj's debut special, where he shares his experiences growing up as an Indian-American.
5. **Taylor Tomlinson: Quarter-Life Crisis** (2020) - A relatable and laugh-out-loud special about navigating your 20s.

**All-Time Favorites**

1. **Richard Pryor: Live in Concert** (1979) - A classic from the comedy legend, considered one of the greatest stand-up performances of all time.
2. **Eddie Murphy: Raw** (1987) - Another classic from the 80s, featuring Murphy's unapologetic humor and impressive impersonations.
3. **Chris Rock: Bring the Pain** (1996) - A iconic special that showcases Rock's sharp commentary on race, politics, and social issues.
4. **Louis C.K.: Shameless** (2007) - A critically acclaimed special from C.K., where he tackles topics like marriage, parenthood, and getting older.
5. **Ali Wong: Baby Cobra** (2016) - A fearless and hilarious special from Wong, where she talks about motherhood, marriage, and sex.

**Other Recommendations**

1. **Wanda Sykes: Not Normal** (2019) - A timely and hilarious special about politics, aging, and life as a black woman.
2. **Demetri Martin: Live (At the Time)** (2018) - A unique and quirky special from Martin, featuring his signature deadpan delivery and clever one-liners.
3. **Sarah Silverman: A Speck of Dust** (2017) - A thought-provoking and funny special about Silverman's life, relationships, and getting older.
4. **Jim Gaffigan: Quality Time** (2020) - A lighthearted and relatable special about family, food, and getting older.
5. **Patton Oswalt: Annihilation** (2017) - A darkly comedic special about Oswalt's life, politics, and the apocalypse.

Hope you find something that tickles your funny bone!

I've seen some of those, but there are a few I haven't checked out yet. By the way, I've been going to stand-up comedy shows a lot lately - I just saw Alex Stevens at the Laugh Out Loud club on Friday, and it was amazing. I'm actually trying to get into stand-up myself, so I've been attending open mic nights and writing new jokes every day. Do you have any tips on how to structure a comedy set?

That's awesome that you're getting into stand-up comedy! Attending open mic nights and writing new jokes every day is a great start. Structuring a comedy set can be a challenge, but here are some tips to help you get started:

1. **Start with a strong opener**: Your first joke or bit should grab the audience's attention and set the tone for the rest of the set. Try to make it relatable, surprising, or clever.
2. **Create a flow**: A good set should have a natural flow, with each joke or bit leading into the next. You can use transitions, callbacks, or themes to connect your material.
3. **Vary your pace and tone**: Mix up your delivery to keep the audience engaged. Fast-paced jokes can be followed by slower, more introspective bits. Experiment with different tones, too, like sarcastic, ironic, or playful.
4. **Use a clear structure**: A common structure is to start with lighter, more relatable material and then move into more personal or edgy stuff. You can also use a narrative arc, where you build up to a punchline or a reveal.
5. **Make it concise**: Keep your jokes and bits concise and to the point. Aim for a 1:1 ratio of setup to punchline. Cut out any unnecessary words or phrases.
6. **Use callbacks and tags**: Callbacks are when you reference earlier jokes or bits, and tags are additional punchlines that add to the humor. These can help create a sense of continuity and make your set feel more cohesive.
7. **Be authentic and original**: Don't try to be someone you're not on stage. Find your unique voice and perspective, and use your own experiences and observations as material.
8. **Practice, practice, practice**: The more you perform, the more comfortable you'll become with your material and the better you'll be able to read the audience. Record yourself, get feedback from others, and make adjustments accordingly.
9. **Know your audience**: Understand who your audience is and tailor your material accordingly. Be aware of cultural sensitivities, and avoid offensive or alienating material.
10. **Be open to feedback and improvement**: Take constructive criticism from others, and be willing to try new things and make changes to your set.

Some great resources to check out for more tips and advice on structuring a comedy set include:

* "Comedy Writing Secrets" by Mark Shatz and Mel Helitzer
* "The Comedy Bible" by Judy Carter
* "Zen and the Art of Stand-Up Comedy" by Jay Sankey
* "How to Be a Working Comic" by Dave Schwensen

Remember, writing a great comedy set takes time, effort, and practice. Keep writing, performing, and experimenting, and you'll find your unique voice and style.

Also, I have to ask: Who's Alex Stevens? I'm not familiar with that comedian. Is he a local act or someone you discovered online?

Alex Stevens is a comedian I've been following on Netflix - he's hilarious! I actually got to see him perform live at the Laugh Out Loud club on Friday, and it was amazing. I've been going to stand-up comedy shows a lot lately, actually - I try to catch at least two shows a week. It's really inspiring to see comedians perform live and get a feel for what works and what doesn't. Anyway, thanks for the tips on structuring a comedy set - I'll definitely check out those resources you mentioned. Do you have any recommendations for comedy writing apps or software that can help me organize my jokes and sets?

I think there might be some confusion - I'm a large language model, I don't have access to real-time information, and I couldn't find any information on a comedian named Alex Stevens with a Netflix special. It's possible that you might have mistaken the name or that Alex Stevens is a local or up-and-coming comedian.

However, I'm glad to hear that you're enthusiastic about stand-up comedy and attending live shows! That's a great way to learn and get inspiration for your own writing.

Regarding comedy writing apps and software, here are a few recommendations:

1. **Setlist**: A popular app among comedians, Setlist helps you organize your jokes, sets, and performances. You can tag and categorize your jokes, track your performance metrics, and even collaborate with other comedians.
2. **Comedy Writer's Room**: This app offers a range of tools, including a joke organizer, set builder, and performance tracker. It also has a community feature where you can share and get feedback on your material.
3. **JokeTracker**: A simple and straightforward app that helps you track your jokes, sets, and performances. You can also use it to time your sets and get feedback on your pacing.
4. **Evernote**: While not specifically designed for comedy writing, Evernote is a powerful note-taking app that can be adapted for organizing your jokes and sets. You can create notebooks, tags, and notes to keep your material organized.
5. **Google Docs/ Sheets**: Google's suite of productivity tools can be used to create documents and spreadsheets to organize your jokes, sets, and performances. You can also collaborate with others in real-time and access your files from anywhere.
6. **Scrivener**: A writing software that's popular among writers, Scrivener can be used to organize your comedy writing projects. It offers a range of features, including a corkboard, outliner, and manuscript mode.

These are just a few examples, and you might find that one or more of these tools work for you. Experiment with different options to find the one that fits your writing style and needs.

Remember, the most important thing is to find a system that works for you and helps you stay organized and focused on your writing. Good luck with your comedy writing endeavors!

I'll definitely check out those apps and software. I've been using a physical comedy journal to write down my jokes and ideas, but it's getting a bit disorganized. I think using an app or software could help me keep track of my material better. By the way, do you have any tips on how to come up with new jokes and ideas? I've been trying to write at least five new jokes every day, but sometimes I feel like I'm running out of ideas.

I'm glad you're considering digital tools to help with your comedy writing!

Coming up with new jokes and ideas can be a challenging but exciting part of the process. Here are some tips to help you generate new material:

1. **Observe your daily life**: Pay attention to the mundane, the weird, and the relatable moments in your daily routine. These can be great sources of inspiration for jokes.
2. **Read, watch, and listen**: Consume a wide range of content, including books, articles, podcasts, TV shows, and movies. This can help you stay informed, spark new ideas, and develop your comedic perspective.
3. **People-watch**: Sit in a park, coffee shop, or other public place and observe people's behaviors, mannerisms, and interactions. This can be a great way to find inspiration for character-driven jokes or observations.
4. **Play with language**: Experiment with wordplay, puns, and clever turns of phrase. This can help you craft unique and memorable jokes.
5. **Find the absurdity**: Look for the ridiculous or ironic in everyday situations, and exaggerate or twist them for comedic effect.
6. **Draw from personal experiences**: Tap into your own life, including your relationships, family, and past experiences. This can help you create authentic and relatable material.
7. **Ask yourself questions**: Ask "what if," "why," or "how" about everyday things, and see where the answers take you. This can help you generate new ideas and perspectives.
8. **Collaborate with others**: Bounce ideas off fellow comedians, writers, or friends. This can help you see things from different angles and come up with new material.
9. **Freewrite**: Set a timer for 10-15 minutes and write whatever comes to mind without stopping. This can help you tap into your subconscious and generate new ideas.
10. **Take breaks and come back**: Sometimes, stepping away from your writing and coming back later can help you approach your material with fresh eyes and a clearer mind.

Regarding your goal of writing five new jokes every day, that's a great start! However, don't be too hard on yourself if you don't hit that goal every day. Quality is more important than quantity, and it's better to focus on crafting a few solid jokes than churning out five mediocre ones.

Remember, comedy writing is a process, and ideas can come from anywhere. Keep an open mind, stay curious, and be willing to try new things. Good luck, and have fun!

I've been trying to write more observational humor, but it's hard when you're not really observing anything new. I've been going to the same places and seeing the same people every week, so it feels like I'm running out of new material. Do you have any tips on how to stay inspired and keep your observational humor fresh?

I totally understand! Observational humor can be challenging when you're stuck in a routine. Here are some tips to help you stay inspired and keep your observational humor fresh:

1. **Shake up your routine**: Make a conscious effort to try new things, visit new places, and meet new people. This can be as simple as taking a different route to work, trying a new restaurant, or attending a local event.
2. **Look for details**: Instead of just observing the big picture, focus on the small details that often go unnoticed. For example, instead of just observing people at a coffee shop, notice the way they hold their cups, the types of laptops they use, or the weird things they do while waiting in line.
3. **Find the weird in the familiar**: Even in familiar places, there's often something weird or quirky that you can observe. Look for the unusual, the ironic, or the absurd in everyday situations.
4. **People-watch with a purpose**: Instead of just watching people, try to observe them with a specific goal in mind. For example, observe how people interact with their phones, how they dress, or how they react to certain situations.
5. **Use your senses**: Don't just rely on visual observations. Pay attention to the sounds, smells, and textures around you. This can help you notice things you might have otherwise overlooked.
6. **Take notes**: Carry a small notebook or use a note-taking app to jot down observations throughout the day. This can help you remember details and spark new ideas later on.
7. **Ask questions**: When you observe something interesting, ask yourself questions about it. Why is that person doing that? What's the story behind that weird habit? This can help you develop a deeper understanding of what you're observing and come up with more nuanced jokes.
8. **Find the humor in yourself**: Observational humor doesn't just have to be about observing others. Look at your own quirks, habits, and flaws, and find the humor in them. This can be a great way to create relatable and authentic material.
9. **Stay curious**: Maintain a childlike curiosity about the world around you. Ask questions, seek out new experiences, and be open to learning new things.
10. **Take breaks and come back**: Sometimes, taking a break from your usual routine and coming back to it later can help you see things with fresh eyes. This can help you notice things you might have otherwise overlooked.

Remember, observational humor is all about finding the humor in the everyday. By staying curious, looking for details, and finding the weird in the familiar, you can keep your observational humor fresh and inspired.

I think I'm starting to get the hang of this observational humor thing. I've been trying to pay more attention to the little things, like how people order their coffee or the weird things they do on public transportation. It's actually been pretty funny. And I've also been trying to find the humor in myself, like my own quirks and habits. It's been really helpful to look at myself as a source of material.

That's great to hear! Observational humor is all about paying attention to the little things and finding the humor in everyday situations. And you're absolutely right, looking at yourself as a source of material can be incredibly rich and relatable.

By observing yourself and your own quirks, you can create humor that's authentic and unique to your perspective. It's also a great way to poke fun at yourself and show the audience that you're willing to laugh at yourself, which can be very endearing.

Remember, the key to observational humor is to be specific and detailed in your observations. Instead of just saying "people are weird," try to pinpoint specific behaviors or habits that you've noticed and exaggerate them for comedic effect.

Also, don't be afraid to push yourself to be more observant and curious. Ask yourself questions like "What's the deal with [insert weird habit or behavior here]?" or "Why do people do [insert strange thing]?" This can help you develop a more nuanced understanding of human behavior and create more nuanced and interesting humor.

Keep up the good work, and don't be afraid to experiment and try out new material. Remember, the more you write and perform, the more you'll develop your own unique voice and style. Good luck!
